Expectation1: Ensure compliance with tax laws and regulations.
Situation1: A seminar is being offered on potential tax law changes that may occur in the next few years.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I glance at the clock on my desk, heart pounding. As an accountant, I know how crucial it is to stay ahead of tax law changes—there’s a seminar starting in ten minutes that could help me ensure my clients remain compliant. Missing it could mean falling behind, risking mistakes, or even penalties for those who trust me. But as a citizen, I feel a different pull. My district’s candidate forum is streaming live right now, and this election feels more important than ever. I want to listen, ask questions, and make an informed choice. I owe it to my community to participate, to be more than just a bystander. The weight of both roles presses on me—professional responsibility on one side, civic duty on the other. I stare at my laptop, torn, knowing I can’t give my full attention to both. My mind races, anxiety building as I try to decide which expectation I’ll have to let down.
